Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Research and time management
Knowledge of how to conduct a research project on a particular topic.
Strong research skills, communication with an academic advisor, and managing a long-term project.

This semester I laid the groundwork for my senior thesis by collecting my primary and secondary sources, doing oral history interviews, writing literature review and paragraphs, and having bi-weekly meetings with my senior thesis advisor. I am ready to dive deeper into the topic and finish my research process over the winter break.
I developed the skill to do extensive research on a topic. Moreover, I learned how to concentrate on the main topic and to constraint the scope of my thesis to focus on the more important questions.

Working on the senior essay has given me a better appreciation for the task of the historian than any of my other coursework in the major. Assembling a history on my own, to write at length about, has been an eye-opening experience so far.
I got a really good start on my thesis. Meeting with the librarian was really helpful, and I feel like I am better prepared to form an argument for such a long paper.

This semester I learned how to navigate the national archives and records administration and do proper research there. This is not as easy as it sounds and is a very valuable skill to have learned!  Besides that, the main skill I developed this semester was how to plan and stay on top of a long term project.
I learned how to do a better job of researching a senior essay.
I improved my research skills and learned how to use citation tools like Zotera. I also learned a significant amount of content knowledge about my topic.
Working with a faculty advisor has been fun.
Learning to research and write a in-depth historical paper.

Professor Allen has helped me think about how to find archives, how to engage with them, and how to read historiography. I feel very well prepared to write the senior essay, and I feel like I have taken a good course on how to be a historian.
Research and planning skills so far.
Hmm...none?

You learn how to begin writing a major research paper. The first semester of the Senior Essay, I think, is focused entirely on research. You identify your primary sources and dive into their analysis.
I learned more about research and appreciated the one-on-one relationship discussion with the Professor.
I have learned to be very critical of the sources I select to use for my research. I have also learned to be more critical of the scope of my essay.
I have greatly enjoyed my first semester working with Professor Semmel on my senior essay. I will provide full comments on my course evaluation for next semester once I've finished my essay.
I found that the success of this course depends entirely on one's advisor -- I happened to have an very cooperative and caring one that helped me throughout the research process.

Strengths: Almost none, though this is necessary for distinction
Weaknesses: Incredibly disorganized, poor communication from the department, and variable experiences depending on how engaged your advisor is
Very useful deadlines provided to structure your research and thinking.
It is a self-structure project.
They are good, since they force the student to have deadlines and it makes the work easier and more manageable.

Strengths:
Ability to work at ones own pace
Ability to choose a topic that is personally interesting 

Weaknesses:
Lack of structure can be dangerous 
Material due at deadlines are not always relevant to final result
Professor Wilson is an excellent advisor.
I suppose it might be good to have more due in the fall. Another five pages or requirements about having come up with a thesis, something like that.

It's an independent project, so not much to say here. However, I appreciated the assignment deadlines throughout the semester and feel well-positioned to approach the writing process in earnest next semester.
Lots of self-directed time. Weakness: lots of self-directed time.
I love working in the group with Professor Allen's other advisees, and I love the extra deadlines that Professor Allen adds. It made me feel very on top of my work in the senior essay.
Could be nice to have an optional seminar time where seniors with similar essay topics have the opportunity to meet up and talk about/workshop each other's theses.
There are busywork assignments and little meaningful interaction with the department.
I think there should be more deadlines staggered throughout the semester. I think I would be better prepared for the spring semester if I had more than a ten-page draft completed.

The senior essay process is pretty disorganized at the department level and relies very heavily on the advisors to provide organization for students. This works when you have an advisor who invests in their students. I imagine it's tough when you don't.

THERE IS NOT ENOUGH GUIDANCE IN THE HISTORY DEPARTMENT FOR THE MAJOR OR THE THESIS! Literally all we get at the end of junior year and during senior year is one short meeting with 100+ students in the room about our timeline and picking advisors and stuff, but nothing else. We get ONE short packet about the senior essay that isn't even available online and a DUS that has 3 hours of office hours a week for 300+ majors. Honestly it makes no sense. There is no help with picking an advisor, no guidance on how to do a lot of things correctly, and honestly not enough professors to advise students. 

MAKE THE ADMINS MORE AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS, especially the DUS and the Senior Essay Advisor, and maybe offer a few options for meetings for the majors or even running meetings throughout the semester where people could drop in to actually learn what they're supposed to do.
It is difficult to prioritize this essay during the first semester of the year before I haver had a chance to do primary source research.
I have greatly enjoyed my first semester working with Professor Semmel on my senior essay. I will provide full comments on my course evaluation for next semester once I've finished my essay.
Again, it is necessary for the major, but the essay director really needs to consider revamping the process.
Yes, it is definitely a fantastic experience.
Certainly. I would definitely recommend the year-long thesis course.
Personally, I think the two-semester thesis is better for the end result, and the time to achieve that.
The two-semester history thesis option is definitely better!
If youre a senior history major you dont really have a choice!
I would recommend.
It's required if you're majoring in history, so definitely graduate.
Everyone should be a history major!
If you're taking a senior thesis in history
Absolutely, everyone should have an adviser as engaged as Professor Allen.

The history department is, as far as I can tell, the best department at Yale. It's also the best undergraduate history department on earth--few would debate that. Given that esteem, the pitiful senior essay program is only more disappointing. This needs to be fixed.

If you are writing the full-year senior essay, then this course is required. Take advantage of this time to meet regularly with your advisor. Get as much research and writing done as possible  you don't want to have too much on your plate going into the spring.
Absolutely!

NOT UNTIL ITS BETTER ORGANIZED AND PROVIDES ACTUAL GUIDANCE TO THE STUDENTS EVEN THOUGH IT'S REQUIRED. SERIOUSLY HISTORY DEPARTMENT, COULD YOU AT LEAST PRETEND TO CARE ABOUT YOUR UNDERGRADS??? HOW ARE YOU SUPPOSED TO BE THE BEST HISTORY DEPARTMENT IN THE COUNTRY IF YOU DON'T PROVIDE ANY GUIDANCE OR CARE ABOUT YOUR UNDERGRADS?
This is a necessary course.
I have greatly enjoyed my first semester working with Professor Semmel on my senior essay. I will provide full comments on my course evaluation for next semester once I've finished my essay.
